VHWAwNJuJvMYksePwK8jSA.text: As far as traditional pubs go you could do much worse than Chandos near Trafalgar Square.  The large bar with an even larger upstairs room gets very busy very quickly so get there early if you want to bag a table, otherwise you'll have to stand.  The venue is quite dimly lit but has character.  The prices of drinks are great and you can get a bottle of wine for less than £10 which doesn't taste like turps.  The food menu is quite dull but it's okay and the service is good considering how busy it can get.

photos.caption: Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom. Chandos

XBVnBsW3W5eor1tU8eN6iQ.text: Yet another Sam Smith pub worth a mention.  This particular one is located around the corner from the National Gallery and Leicester Square.  A great place to come of a drink with a big group of friends since it is spacious and spread across two floors.  Also your friends will never be able to give the "I'm too broke to go out" excuse, because frankly anyone could afford at least one drink in this pub.  As usual the only thing that is lacking in a Sam Smith pub is a bit of background music to stop the loud chatter of people to get to your head.  But other than that, this place definitely does it for me.

photos.caption: Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom

E-bSvmJsnEheQ0phicxHeg.text: I'm probably going to be made fun of for the 5 star rating on a Samuel Smith pub, but I really don't know what else I would want from a pub.  Downstairs is you standard great pub.  Open and lined with booths.  Classic feel.  There is also room to have a beer outside, weather permitting.  Then the real hero for my is upstairs in the Opera Room.  Fantastic for lounging and the greatest ease of comfort.  I remember the first time I went in I felt like I've been there for years.The location, staff, and regulars are always exceptional.  I'm still not sold on Sam Smith food, but for a great cheap beer in an even better spot, I don't know what could be better.  I really love this place.

OQ7YNFkK6hjs0fA5jQ-kmg.text: Nice place to grab a beer after a walk in central London.

LebMLkLSvBgsI8h-DCeVPA.text: All my favorite Sammy Smith's on tap and plenty of room to lounge around, we must have hit this place 5 times over a two week long trips.  This place gets CROWDED so beware on a weekend evening.  Best on Monday or Tuesday when the crowds are far smaller.

tF584aTFLR5SjLbqDUV2Mw.text: The Chandos is pretty much the pinnacle of Perfect Pub-Crawl Pub. Loud, raucous, centrally located, and filled to the brim with young and silly Fancy Dress parties, it is the ideal place to stop off for a quick pint or two in a kick-ass location.Being located so close to Trafalgar Square, Leicester Square, the National Portrait Gallery, and the bustling West End, The Chandos is a ridiculously popular place to  grab a drink As every review before mine has pointed out, this place is CROWDED. At all hours of the day. If you are lucky enough to find a space to hunker down, grab it and don't let it go as seats are insanely hard to come by. And the place is huuuuge, too; two huge floors of stools, booths, couches, and little alcoves, so it takes quite a lot of people to fill it up. And the Sammy Smiff prices mean that even if you're skint, you can have a totally decent night out here on the cheap. Wheeee!I can't really fault The Chandos for being unpleasantly crowded the way that some other pubs get. The patrons consist largely of stag parties and other fancy dress groups, so it is kind of hard to be peeved about having to squeeze between a Sexy Cop and a guy in a giant banana costume to get to the loo. If you're looking for a relaxed, civilized night out, you're definitely in the wrong place. If you love cheep beer, shouted/slurred drinking songs, and people watching of the ridiculous clientele, definitely give The Chandos an evening of your time.

qLTZKXtXjes-xxd9RiV_yw.text: Great pub, slap bang in the centre of London, reasonable and fairly large. The "problem" is that, because of this, it is almost invariably full to the gunnels! There's usually more room upstairs than down, but most times I've been there of an evening, I've had to stand for a while before swooping, vulture-like, upon an empty table.It's a Sam Smith's, so own-brand only, but this makes it cheap(er) and their beer selection is very wide indeed.A fine place to drink in Central London.

SyGsbJvpfgGwPVWkQztJHg.text: This pub is a favourite of two friends of mine, and we usually meet up with them here. Happy to do it, since it's easy on the wallet. Good ol' Sam Smith.Like Annie W., I've only ever been able to grab a seat in the Opera Room upstairs. The very private, walled booths downstairs always look so fun and exclusive... it almost makes me feel shamed to walk past and peer in to see if there are any vacancies. And then begrudgingly wandering upstairs, defeated.One of these days, Chandos... I'll get a booth. And I will WIN.

VPx9MabBJG1fr73AZ9sPQg.text: I got a booth! I got a booth!After an angry look from a city boy who also wanted the table.But I'm afraid to say, while the privacy and space were great (along with the feeling of superiority after beating Joe Smart for the spot) the acoustics weren't so good when chatting across the table."What's that?" I hear you cry.Actually I didn't.Exactly.

4-qMGXprpphL0Y0FM_-dZg.text: I went on a Friday night and I was not a fan. The place was overly crowded, hot inside, and there wasn't anywhere to sit. It's a drink and stand type of bar for the after work crowd. Not really my scene. No music, too bright, no brand name beer, and it closes early. The drinks are cheap so that's probably the only plus.. I was only there for about 20 minutes, had a beer and left. Maybe it's different on other nights and maybe their food is great but I can only base it on my experience. There are many pubs around the area...I would try others before visiting Chandos

eJ7EIIGxKNdppolaGPZoCQ.text: If I'm around Trafalgar Square and fancy a pint, I generally end up in The Chandos! It's a Samuel Smith pub, so the beers are well priced and it has a traditional pub feel to it. Lots of dark wood, a cosy seating areas etc. Upstairs there is a  large lounge area with some very colourful stained glass windows. A mate of mine recently showed me an iPhone app called "Smith Finder" bit.ly/TxB5ki that features this pub and a load of other interesting old pubs. Our "couple of pints" ended up turning into a bit of an impromptue pub crawl!

Ppg9LYWVNRxflydMwkD6MQ.text: This is a nice pub and because it's a Samuel Smith's one it's not too expensive either. For those not familiar with Samuel Smith's you won't be finding any of the brand names or fancy bottled beers here. The Yorkshire run brewery does just that, they brew their own ales, stouts and lagers and that's all they sell in their pubs. All is not lost though as they have equivalents/alternatives to most of the mainstream brands and because they don't spend heaps on fancy ad campaigns for them they're much cheaper. Lager for example is £2.15 a pint or £2.90 if you go for the fancy continental version - both of which are very drinkable!That's Sam Smith's, so what about this particular pub... well it's a wee bit shabby but in your typical London pub way, more well worn-in than worn out, perfect for a few sneaky cheap drinks after work. They have a separate upstairs bar/lounge where you can order cheap food (scampi and chips/steak and ale pie type stuff). Probably not the kind of place you'd go to on a first date as you'd maybe want something a bit smarter but for more relaxed beers with friends/workmates it's perfect and ridiculously cheap for central London!

dW9EeGi3BMJnkIubA2UppQ.text: I work nearby, so the Chandos is the usual post-work pub for good cheap beer (seems they upped the price of Alpine to £2.32 ... but with prices like that, who can complain?!). Always crowded, but that's what makes it a good pub, in my opinion. Haven't tried the food (do I want to?), but a great atmosphere, super central, and I'd like to think that those at the bar have spotted us as regulars (one can only hope!).

3c399DnoQUxCS9tNrUZTLA.text: Both times I was only upstairs in the Opera Room so my experiences are based on that. It does get really packed after 5 or 6 pm so best to go a bit early and stake out a seat. They have lots of comfy couches and seating arrangements great for grabbing a pint of cider, order a fat plate of chips to share, and lounge around for an hour or two. It's lively and loud but not to the point of shouting conversations (also, no loud music playing in the background, thumbs up!). Prices are quite cheap, about £2-3 for a pint of cider or beer and location is prime. So come and help yourselves to many rounds of Strongbow on tap!

TflBjzsR3tIdc00C_tPIWg.text: Another amazing Samuel Smiths pub, who'd have thought you could get a cheap pint over looking Trafalgar Square! Well in the Chandos it is possible. A great meeting place if you're having a central night out, or pop in after looking around the National Portrait gallery or other local treat. The downstairs bar has round tables and booths for you to squash around, the upstairs bar, called the opera room, has a slightly different feel but is just as busy. Arrive EARLY if you're planning on spending the whole evening here as the place gets super busy.

LKRo3wv-QnHcbRPCzSh5kA.text: Went at lunchtime. Perfect location, just a stone's throw away in Trafalgar Square. It was nice and calm inside which was the perfect contrast to the crowds outside. The Opera Room on the second floor was lovely. The prices were very reasonable for its location and the quality of the food and drink (I had a steak pie which I really enjoyed).

ot2Cy9Sa0V-qNFXVHm-JiQ.text: Lovely atmosphere, fantastic place to spend some time with friends.

cEPpYGncgYYRdoBt5fECbg.text: I've never been upstairs, only in the bit downstairs. A favorite with those I work with, the beer is good and cheap & it's always completely crammed with the after work crowd. They serve food but I don"t know if I would trust it.One thing I think I should mention. Last time I was there--last week--a toilet seat was missing in the ladies' room.

gleFLKUQ8vPoslOpCeFAQQ.text: Lovely lovely pub. Got there early and scored a snug, and settled in for a few pints and a nice spot of relaxation after a whole day's walking. They also have a nice selection of drinks for those who aren't drinking alcohol, unlike some pubs where all you can get is watered-down post-mix.

EVTLj5OvKJ8VyrJbhabk4Q.text: A friend of mine discovered The Chandos last year when he wanted to host some cheap London leaving drinks. This pub boasts the cheapest pints in London. I'm not sure if a cheap pint in London is possible but we seem to go there every time, returning with a little change in our pockets so it can't be a bad thing!There are booths in the downstairs part of the pub, this is great for groups. Upstairs, the pub has a different vibe - red carpets, sparse seating, a little cramped. The drinks here are... OK. I'm a wine drinker and I've had better but that's why I guess the pub is quite cheap, you can't have it all.There are usually lots of tourists in this pub since it's a stone throws away from Trafalgar Square. If you're going to go to The Chandos, make sure it's on a week night, it'll be a little quieter and you'll get a seat.

mjZ3aVXjbVWgP82Uj-G1eA.text: Monopoly Pub Crawl - Stop #19 - Trafalgar Square (Red)A short distance away from the previous pub, we found the Chandos to finish off the red color group. As far as pubs go, this isn't the greatest but it has an excellent location a stone's throw away from Trafalgar Square. Essentially, it gets the job done but as with most places in this area it's usually rammed on the weekend. It is alright for large groups most of the time though due to the large size and as a Sam Smith's pub you do get a slightly different range of ales. But let's be honest, for most of us, brown ales taste remarkably similar but at least it's not a 'Spoons!Other than that, I don't have much to say about the Chandos. It has the usual selection of booze on offer and could easily be a copy of oh so many pubs. It's a place to get drunk, not experience London pub culture sadly and you are better off enjoying the drink deals at All Bar One or Pitcher & Piano franchises close by.

WVbUBuuFWER-Irui4VmQJg.text: I stumbled in here about nine months months ago, accidentally, while seeking shelter from the rain before a Christmas choir at St Martins in the Fields, and I just want to say that from all the pubs I had been in throughout London, this was by far my favorite. It had been exactly what I had expected from an English pub: full of Brits (and not tourists), and not your poshy kind of Brit, but the regular working class of 30-50 year olds, no music (I despise this in American bars), and cheap delicious domestic beer (Samuel Smith!!!).The beer selection, despite being only Samuel Smith, were amazing, and Samuel Smith Imperial Stout tastes so much better from the tap than from the glass bottles you get in Boston, Its also cheap as balls. The characters you meet here are amazing and I am dying to come back. I had to leave early for my show, which was especially unfortunate since my brother and I had managed to pounce on a table as soon as a couple had left. I couldn't remember the name of the bar upon leaving, but luckily a little research and the fact that it was the closest Samuel Smith pub to St Martins in the Field made things a little easier.I have no comments on the food as I didn't have any (why I give it a 4 star), but I will be back next month and ready to come here again. I say anyone who loves a great cheap beer and what a pub should actually be like should definitely come here.

z9GrQitELakr3FBfV5zllQ.text: This place is a weird, mixed bag, but I love it all the same. Its location makes it an interesting cross-section for locals and tourists, and cheap beer makes it appealing even if you'd rather go someplace quieter. My friend got slapped in the face by a drunk old man in this pub (while he often deserves to be smacked, this was not the case in this particular incident). It makes me laugh every time I'm in there. The bar staff asked the old gent to leave, which was a pleasant surprise as we were far from the center of attention and the bar was very crowded. It was quickly made a non-issue. Groups cycle in and out of here, so don't be intimidated by the lack of seats when you arrive. If you get a booth, stay forevverrrr.

6HX2LetLR-im4jKQDCg-cg.text: Sorry to say but I had heard good stuff about this place .. We had just taken a seat with our drinks and the staff came in to pick up the empty glasses behind us and made us move for that .. The lady was holding glasses on top of each other and I warned her to be careful .. And boom goes the tower on our table .. Luckily no one was hurt from the glass all around ..  I had beer on my pants which was def not cool .. Reason I'm writing a bad review is that mistakes do happen but the staff didn't even show basic courtesy of apologizing or offering us another drink which was all over us ... Come on guys at least treat Ur customers properly .. It doesn't take a lot to say sorry ..

4IexXyWYIouYxV1lYHytMQ.text: The place isvery accessible and convenient to everyone; it is located in a touristy spot inthe centre of London. The place, staff, and service are always excellent. I trulylove this place. A fine and nice place to drink here in Central London.

uINr6f7pxxVGp5IKX_wWbw.text: While visiting London for the Olympics just last week, I stopped by this bar because a friend of mine said it was the perfect spot for a beer with my boo boo (yes I did just call my SO that...)I think we came here on an off-night (Sunday evening) and it was pretty empty. Call me dumb but I didn't think London had off-nights when it came to drinking.. but now I am informed and you should be too. Brits drink a lot .. like a lot a lot .. but not all the time and especially not Sunday nights.The bar itself was so classic. Reminded me of a rustic home or old Hollywood parlor. Very pretty decor, relaxing spot for a good beer, and the staff was super duper nice. It is located in a touristy spot but to my pleasant surprise, wasn't filled with tourists also there for the Olympics like I was so it was cool to chit chat with true locals.

DGNRTnPREYjhMc-X8poXtw.text: This place is for sure a 4 to 5 star spot, I'm giving it a sentimental 5 star rating.  I always find myself here every time I visit London, if you are anywhere near Trafalgar Square and want to hit a true London pub come here.  Its a two story pub, I'm a second floor fan.  Its slightly hidden and a great local spot where you can sit back and relax from exploring London.  Its the perfect place to meet friends for drinks, great setup for relaxing and conversation with those huge comfy leather sofas.  The food is alright, I mean its an English pub food and your reading a Yelp review... you aren't coming here for food.  Drinks are affordable, its a Sam Smiths pub. I've managed to find this pub every time I've been to London since I was 14.  I just found out after a conversation with my Dad that this is where we celebrated when my family was granted permanent visa's to live in the US when I was ten.  That made me smile, I will always get a drink here when I visit London.

photos.caption: Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom. I suck at finding this place hope this helps others!

sZOCQZDsJMDaerXaEJTitw.text: I visited in 2009, and I still dream about the chicken and mushroom pie I had.  I have yet to find anything similar in NY, but keep on searching.  This pub was PACKED when I visited and I can see why.  I loved the relaxed atmosphere and amazing food.  Before leaving I snapped a picture of the pub so I can always remember this place and hopefully visit again!

photos.caption: Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom. out of this world chicken and mushroom pie

9Ir3bKzsRE2FLJ0zs-VCTw.text: Exceptionally rude bar staff and bar supervisor. A petty dispute over an innocently spilled drink soured our visit. The worst attitude I've ever seen from a bar supervisor in 10 years of drinking in London. A definite avoid and a poor example of London pub culture - visited 21st Feb 2013.

XfuKP_ONfvy4INi9w8lA_A.text: I like The Chandos, it's that rare breed of a quintessential English boozer of what you see is what you get. I have to say that whenever I've been in there it's always been rammed & very lively - up & downstairs - but at least this shows that it is popular & a decent place for a relaxing, casual drink with friends. I also like that, even with its brilliant location (right near Charing Cross, the Strand, Trafalgar Square), it's not overrun by tourists and seems to be full of the workers on their way home variety instead.The Chandos has pleasant enough bar staff for a central London location & a decent variety of beers, ciders, ales, wines & basically whatever tipple you're after! Oh yeah & more importantly, good crisps!

VfkeELyqIpV3MluQD2nKkQ.text: Shortly after arriving in London, the hubby and I were looking to enjoy some ale and some pub grub.  Rick Steves (who I'm obsessed with, but that's a subject for another day) has never steered me wrong before, and certainly did not where The Chandos is concerned.  As far as I can tell (keeping in mind that I am American born and bred), this is an authentic British Pub tucked away in a cozy corner of the Covent Garden area.  It seemed a haven from the more touristy spots.  They had a really nice beer selection, perfect to wash down some bangors and mash.  Seating upstairs in the Opera Room was cozy and comfortable and it was an enjoyable place to spend our first afternoon in London while we got our bearings a bit.  Check it out!

qeE1TlSTUW9HCQNbV37YtA.text: The Chandos is a sanctuary, a haven, a space trapped in time where the outside world doesn't matter. Just off Trafalgar Square it's a world away from the bustle and hustle on its doorstep, with dark wood, draft beers and a coolness that keeps the harshest excesses of summer 2013 at bay. London is a big city and this is an old establishment, but there's a homeliness to this place that let's everyone feel that they found it themselves: this can be your pub just as much as the chap nodding off over there, the small groups tucked away in the window-side booths, the city folk downing a swift pint before their journeys out to the suburbs. Make this your regular central London watering hole and time and again it won't disappoint.

6NHR3iKTR0fX-jGRrqqnig.text: This place wasn't terrible, but when you walk in you get the feeling you're in a pub that's part of a larger chain.  I did like the location in trafalgar square, and the comfy couches and free wifi.  But there is a huge breeze on the upstairs level from the door that leads to the toilets.  The drink prices were also a little higher than they needed to be.

nJXK2OfLV5yKiHK6lJneEA.text: As close as you can get to Trafalgar Square without actually being shat on by a pigeon, The Chandos somehow manages to ward off a large majority of the tourists and leaves a pleasant work-like atmosphere for locals and the like.Perfect for those who travel out of Charing Cross, it's a Sam Smiths, so you know what you're in for. Reasonable priced self brewed lagers and ciders and a hella lot of wood and dimly lit areas. No music in here, so get your chat on. It's not really a first date place is it, but it's ruddy brilliant for meeting with friends before a night in Soho or for a slap-on-the-back-you've-just-made-it-through-another-week drinks session on a Friday eve.Never had the food - I must get round to doing this in the name of Yelp!

36SAFHB72DMFE-82dpgWKw.text: My partner in slime and I pretty much stumbled on this one just walking around and decided to go in for a pint; really glad we did! Cheap beer that my partner loves, and ohhh the cider. I believe the cider is more expensive than the beer but it's so well worth it, miles better than the draught ciders at most places I've been (most serve Strongbow, which I find to be wretched). This is my first time at a Samuel Smiths pub and I'm going to make sure I look out for more ;D

YAsEfKjWfVXzZukVNDQi8g.text: Great little pub, particularly the Opera Bar upstairs.  Nice atmosphere and no background music - great central place to meet up with friends.

4RfZcJhxUeYiicEKsJTLZA.text: The atmosphere of this pub can best be described as quiet, however it's cheap and has a great location, and the food tastes pretty good too, and is very well priced for what you get. It didn't completely agree with me a couple of hours later. Shame the fireplace wasn't real or it could have been much nicer! Worth a visit if you're in the area :)

_ulE7wFUqz4s0jAyT1AP8g.text: Jane C's review has prompted me to place mine for this excellent place. Central location, near the brights lights of Leicester Square, and that old bloke atop the big pedestal. Wonderful Sam Smith's ale on draught - I love that stuff, and sooo cheap.Tues night, after 7.30pm, plenty of seating upstairs - nice area, with it's own bar. Sensible!Downstairs was busy, but quitened down later. I've passed this pub when it has been absolutely rammed - so appreciate earlier comments re: seating, space and general popularity.Don't be put off, it's still a great place.I'd throughly recommend this and other Sam Smith pubs in London - there are over 20, I believe.

DwTNQ83AiUBtssunQcPi5g.text: I come here every week with some friends so I do have a lot of affection for the place but I'll try to not let that blind me to it's faults! Firstly I adore Sam smith's pubs in general! Ambiance! No loud music! Cheap, cheap lager! Woo! The Chandos is a pretty good example of such and it's great to find pub slap bang in the middle of tourist land that is so... well I guess, unspoilt. Most of the other pubs in the neighbourhood are grottier and crowded-er, just through sheer day to day throng of people. The Chandos however manages to be avoid the scruffy and have a good mix of regulars, tourists and workers in. It has a nice historic pub decor, with the downstairs more drinking den and the upstairs 'opera' bar more for lounging. It's always, always crowded in the rush hour but upstairs is usually better. Actually, I just don't bother to even look downstairs anymore! I just head straight up to to the Opera Bar. Alcohol, other than beers is certainly more expensive but not out of the central London Price range. Lager and ale on tap so ridiculously cheap however The food is AWFUL! If I've not had chance to eat before I get there I'm stuck with it so I've tried most of the menu and it's dire beyond the dreams of dire. Stogy, stogy microwave veg (always carrots and peas!!!) and mush! AVOID AVOID! The McDonald's is just around the corner - GO THERE!! They used to have a really good menu but they changed it last year when the food menu was standardised across the Sam Smith's chain! A real shame as each pub had found a couple of good things that it did really well. The Chandos could do you a huge, huge bowl of curly fries for £4.50. Alas!   SO really good for as a happy spot for a drink with some pals, but avoid the food at all costs.

Y0rim3GmPMx1-fIpvMH69g.text: Not to be a Debbie Downer or anything but every time I got made redundant from my old job me and my work mates would all come here and get drunk to cheer ourselves up. It was actually quite fun!This pub is a good old Sammy Smiths venue so you'll find own brand drinks and food served here only. It all tastes a little funny and different but it's abut a third of the price of any other pub in this area, overall making it a winner. They also have really cosy sofas so snuggle down in if you come here on a week night and want to get up close and personal with a date! Only warning is, most people know how cheap this place is so if you come here after 5.30 you are highly unlikely to get a seat.

If_ZA93FH1o5YeLxJRJFNA.text: A great place to unwind after a busy week! A very good location combined with bustling ambiance and friendly staff. I've never been to the second floor where they serve food as all the fun is downstairs at the ground floor where there are decent cheese toasts and a humble selection of crisps and peanuts you can nibble while enjoying your drinks. There is a good selection of beers of which my boyfriend is a fan and I like the cocktails and wines they offer. This time I tried the white Zinfandel and I liked it.Hadn't I seen the rolls of toilet paper being stored on the bathroom floor, I would have given this place 5 stars... but I guess the more you drink, the less you start to care each time you go to the toilet and see these. Anyway, I love this place and will keep on going there because I always have a good time.

bRIYqG8xIOnIulbFkghypg.text: As a Yank, this hits me as weird that you would close at 11pm or so on a Thursday night when you still have plenty of people and plenty of people on the street.  Oh well this was close to my hotel, and my local friends wanted to have a few beers without to hit the insanity that is SOHO.  They have ales so you can drink those, wasn't extremely expensive given that it is a block off Trafalgar Square.If you are in the area and need a beer, why not.  I do like going pub hopping looking for ales that I haven't consumed before.

f-saweLJ940O5p9SXDbEAg.text: Nice ambiance.  The beer is good (but most English pubs have good draws).  Needed to go up to the bar to order.  Can't say much about the food as we only got a basic app.  Nice stop in the afternoon to take a break.

dWH-4dU5AsB9-ZF_h74M_g.text: Had a blast here last night, great food, great staff, even better drinks. We grabbed a pint downstairs and made our way up stairs to the air conditioned section and ended up spending 3 hours drinking and meeting a bunch of people. Can't wait to go back.

photos.caption: Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom. Amazing hot dog

-XPyoYKnlyWEDxqy4CeOnQ.text: Nice location close to Trafalgar Square, comfy seating,  very friendly staff - many from Australia, pub lunch menu around 5/8 pounds the meal and 4 pounds for a pint. I even needed to charge my phone and the bar man offered to charge it behind the counter ;)

photos.caption: Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom

4RvSNDRw04ba61KdZ_2wNg.text: The Chandos is another one of the Sam Smith's pubs in Central London which means that you are not charged an arm and a leg for beer despite its proximity to Trafalgar Square.As a creature of habit I usually go for the Alpine Lager but the other drinks go down well. I would happily recommend The Chandos to any tourist in the Trafalgar Square area.

Zj5HsSygM0hyyaE6MuhTSA.text: Sam Smith's pub in a very central location close to Trafalgar Square and Charing Cross railway station. The interior is nothing special, just your typical city centre pub. A great place to meet up with your mates before moving on somewhere better. Due to location, tends to get very busy.

DEl-S2fqOeC1NUVz-TDdvg.text: An extremely busy Sam Smiths Pub just down from Leicester Square . Lots of wood as you would expect on a traditional pub . Beer price and quality was ok . Getting a seat forget it !!!!

rfY74x3QmJvi0x9T6HM7XQ.text: I love coming here once in a while for a pint.  It's a really great place and seems to be a very traditional pub.  No TVs or trivia machines here.  The whole place seems to try and keep people talking to each other, as opposed to distracted by other "stuff".The beer here is really tasty as well!  I love the comfy spots around the whole place to sit and chat.  Would highly recommend coming here!

izI4ZjvNKWVXyCoD5HTQOw.text: Delicious fish and chips and chicken pie. Sam Smith beer on tap only. Place gets pretty pack, food service is on the 2nd floor. Bartender was very nice and helpful. Great place to eat and hang out after a long day of walking around London.

xhB6gZPcpi2v3naMeyoEDQ.text: My party of 5 arrived just as they opened.  A sandwich sign was at the entrance advertising their delicious food.  We were seated and went to the bar to order.  We were informed that they only sold food upstairs.  We walked up the stairs and had a seat.  The waiter informed us  there was a party of 58 coming in soon so we would have to order quickly.  I quickly went to the bar to order.  First I ordered drinks.  Then as I was placing my food order the manager walked in and berated the staff for seating us and taking our order.  I told him I had ordered my drink with the assumption I would be consuming it when I eat.  I asked him to comp it.  He said you will pay and you will not be served lunch.  I asked him why the staff was uninformed about the fact that they were not to serve food to the patrons.  He said he didn't have enough reserved signs to place them on all the tables.  He was really yelling and being abrupt.  Managers who have a party of 58 should communicate to the upstairs and downstairs staff that the restaurant is closed for a private party.  He should not berate his staff publicly.  He should learn service recovery.

Kc5DmoFPPz94H3niCr2yHg.text: Located right behind Trafalgar Square, this is an excellent respite from all the tourists and grime of the inner city. However, like most places located this close to the main city, the food isn't superb. It's pretty good- I got the chicken and ham pie and though it was tasty it seemed like it had maybe been pre made and then heated up right before it was served. The service and ambience are great however! Very casual and our server (a nice American girl) helped lots with choosing a pint to go with our meal. Not sure if i'd return but it definitely is one of the better places in that area.

CbEIl7jn73gJcctAwhiF6g.text: I stopped here for a snack in between a cultured-pack day in London. Or walking all over the city absorbing the beauty, culture and sights!  Having had my experience in the George Inn, I headed straight to the bartender and asked for fish & chips and tea. Of course, I was promptly told that warm drinks are served upstairs!Argh! Rules! I still had not mastered the British way!I headed upstairs and the barmaid took my order and gave me the portable table number (thing).  Being the super sociable person I am, I quickly found a hidden table behind a wall!The fish and chips were delicious & not greasy, the tea was sustaining, and the atmosphere (at around noon) was very quiet. Only few regulars and a tourist table were in the room that would easily handle 50+, or more!

Fja6eraZrvSJu9etXue49Q.text: You wouldn't think that a place so close to the hustle and bustle of Trafalgar Square would have the charm of your local neighbourhood pub, but there you go. After a day of sightseeing and shopping, I was absolutely starving, and dead set on having one good pub meal. I knew I was in a real, honest-to-God pub when I opened up the menu and saw, among the steak-and-kidney pies and sticky toffee pudding, chicken tikka masala and Thai curry. Fabulous.My red pepper and feta quiche (pictured) came with the most delicious salad, so much so that I almost wish that it were the entree. (Although the quiche was pretty darn fabulous, too.) It was also great not to have to ask for vinegar to go with the chips (which were unfortunately a mite soggy).Honestly, though, what made this place was the ambiance, from the cheery server who kept calling me "luv", to the babble of different accents (read: tourist vs. local), to the quintessential Britishness of it all. Long live the pub.

photos.caption: Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom. Red pepper and feta quiche with salad and chips (and vinegar!)

Yjrni4Da07KR07vNGtfO2Q.text: Solid traditional English pub in a great location in front of Trafalgar Sq near the Charring Cross underground.  A Samuel Smith pub with a mostly full list of their offerings exclusively.  Nice closed off booths and lots of floor space for the after work crowds.  Nothing to write home to mum about, but did the job :)

SdIhHXMmhWvn6P5G8w7GSQ.text: The second floor Opera Room has always been one of my favorite lunch spots in London.  We stop in every visit; usually for the first meal.  It's in the heart of the London tourist area yet is still authentic and traditional.  And the decor is outstanding with varied seating made up of booths, tables, couches and stools.  They serve Samuel Smith beers and have the best Bangers & Mash.  The service is always great and the prices are reasonable for the area.  I can't wait for the next visit.

_eRSPzxohVaI9qSaxrvNqw.text: Awesome place! Great place to stop and grab some lunch after a trip to the National Gallery. I loved the traditional look & the staff was so friendly and helpful. Would recommend to anyone in the area!!

pypZckvWHnyx-czsuyXVSg.text: First of all, because this is a Sam Smith's it automatically gets 3 stars.  If that wasn't the rule, I'd probably have given The Chando's 2 stars.  But, because you can rely on Sam Smith's for quality and good prices, 3 stars it is.The pub itself is rather large and, on a Friday afternoon, pretty full but not insanely so.    We were able to find a wee table in the back which pretty quickly turned into two wee tables and a large bench.  We had been hoping for one of the lovely booths but that wasn't to be.  There is also an upstairs area but I didn't see it because I was holding the wee table whilst others scouted for something larger.  Apparently, the upstairs was full, too.  We came with a large group from work and we were all drinking and buying bar snacks.  When a guy came to clear our table full of empty glasses and empty packets of bar snacks, we were chastised for bringing in a can of Coke (an empty can was sitting on the table) and a plastic bag of nuts (it was a peanut and wasabi pea mixture I had leftover from my lunch and had opened for the table to try).  We were threatened with expulsion if it were to happen again.  Seriously.  The guy was a dick about it.  I get not bringing in outside food but when we're clearly not using that food in lieu of buying from the pub what's the problem?  But, whatevs.  Be a dick.  Because this is a Sam Smith's (and close to my work) I'll probably be back but it won't be because of the awesome customer service or friendly atmosphere.

rfV2TlYbpif47zOHW883bQ.text: I initially stepped in and out of the pub because I was concerned with its proximity to major tourist sites and didn't want to be duped into paying for overpriced boring pub food. However, I was pleasantly surprised once I decided to give it a chance how good the food was and how excellent the beer was! It also helped that it was filled with locals. The beers offered are numerous and there are a lot of great food choices including standard pub far but with some extra additions as well. If you're looking for a bite and a pint near Trafalgar, this place is definitely worth a stop.

qJxR79X8SZEUTptAjK53LQ.text: I'm giving 5 stars because I'm also considering the crowd this place attracts.Now, I'm assuming that with the lack of American accents (except my own) there were more locals here than tourists. Which is odd, considering it being so close to Trafalgar Sq. I loved this pub. It was the quintessential cliche image of what an English pub looked like in my mind. I loved all the dark wood that flowed throughout the bottom space (I didn't go upstairs). And I love those booths where you can hide away and read a paper.I love the fact that the beers here are so fucking cheap! But, you'll have to order a Samuel Smith Stout because there ain't no Guinness here. That's fine, I drink Sam Smith back home. I ordered myself a pint and crammed myself in between two blokes and two birds.(giggles in delight at the access of English slang)I sat on an elongated cushioned bench against stained glass windows and just people watched. I watched and I listened. I love the colourful characters that were in here and the warm and people friendly Londoners, or the warmth the hooch brings them. I had an awesome conversation with the blokes sitting next to me and who could resist that charming accent? Come on!Sitting in this pub and drinking a stout, I connected with the Londoners faster in 15 minutes than I did spending 6 days in Paris. And for this, I'll be eternally grateful to this pub.DID I MENTION THE CHEAP ASS BEERS?!

LuUHjwjP3Ec49CJDPSWNnw.text: The Chandos is close to Charings Cross, a Sam Smith establishment, with large draught selection. We came close to 10pm and it was buzzing, plenty of people downstairs with booths, tables and standing room, as well as bar upstairs which was packed, more couches and comfy seating. I loved the traditional feel, not to mention the atmosphere. Friendly and efficient barmen, nice crowd, and great beer/cider. We didn't eat, the kitchen had stopped serving but it was a good place to stop for late drink.

photos.caption: Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom. Samuel smith cider

bcVZ0FDNSnFFp7sqYjXB-w.text: Food is okay. Portions are small, prices are high. It's a tourist trap. They charge extra for condiments, e.g., 50p for ketchup.

BoIaAeTYHbCXl6b4qiuACw.text: We ate lunch at The Chandos after visiting a close by museum.  It was two stories where pub only downstairs, and one can also eat upstairs.  Both the food and the beers were better than average.  I ordered the fish and chips.  We enjoyed coming here as it was there when we were hungry.

WaECV97L1xYNR7IyiHdV5Q.text: This is out favorite place to eat in London.  The fish and chips are amazing and the personnel are friendly

Si3-zWgiZhT7KRwEfxmDGg.text: Good fish and chips, good beer, what more can you ask for while in London.  Prices were reasonable with friendly staff.

0CufpG1flCvmQpnv98OOhg.text: Nice fish and chips, stocked bar, super friendly bar staff and service! Good location, great atmosphere.

CNP7pY1tprMB816A4zx9Vw.text: Seating is very limited but totally worth it! Food is wonderful. Got a taste of British pub life with the whole family! Upstairs room was more spacious!

oGuRphO39rlx1zo-lk9Abw.text: Only had few drinks here but very much enjoyed the atmosphere and service. An authentic english pub.

GLYJ8SP0JzW-1kxJfIpA4A.text: Great pub, so much right about it.  Cheap, good Sam Smiths brews, good food and comfy seats in the upstairs Opera Room, great location across from Trafalgar Square, even great service.

photos.caption: Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom. Sam Smiths stout
Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom. Vegetarian Wellington
Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom. Mac n cheese

fFliEyXhJjahTbnM8CTquw.text: Stopped in for lunch with my 11 year old son. We were both jet lagged having just flown in overnight from Minneapolis. A nice hot plate of fish and chips was just what we needed. Service was fast and friendly. Food was far above average. Neither of us actually had a drink but they had a good selection of alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages.

dZO1s8XiHJpamoxcYcy2Pg.text: This is me and my husbands favorite bar in fact we came here twice while on vacation in London. Great food with excellent service. Staff are friendly and accommodating. We surely missed this place.

ozmO0G_VBxKLCdE0rY6pdg.text: Went here because Rick Steves recommended it in his book. And of course the minute I walk in I see other people in there with Rick Steves books.....go figure lol. But of course, I also saw a lot of locals grabbing a drink after work and socializing. Aka....IT WAS PACKED DURING HAPPY HOUR TIME lol. We had to creep and stalk for a while before we got a table upstairs. The place is a very traditional pub like with people standing, sitting on bar stools to booths, to couches, to single couch chairs/comfy fabric chairs etc. Oh, and its pretty chilly so girls, unless you drinking a good amount you might be chilly upstairs. As for the beer, I can't remember what we had but it was so creamy and smooth, delicious. The food we ordered was fish and chips, chicken masala or something like that and a bunch of those meat pies things (see pics). I have to say honestly none of the food was that good since its pub food lol, so make sure your drinking when your eating here. And considering I can't really drink, wasn't that much fun being their eating pub food sober -_-. lol, but if I could drink I think I would have liked this place more. Oh, and this pub is kid friendly, lots of families when I went. Overall, nice little pub, beer is good, food is meh when your sober, make sure your drinking when you eat the food like all pub/bar food lol. Not a fan as I probably wouldn't go back but its okay.

Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom

yoWgo78yMkqvKVaz7l_GHg.text: We were having a touristy day in London around Trafalgar Square and wanted a pub lunch. I chose this place based on the Yelp reviews.We headed upstairs as there were clear signs telling us food was upstairs. As with most pubs, you sit yourself down wherever you like and order at the bar.They have a really great drinks selection which is why my review is 3 not 2 stars. Staff were extremely friendly. I had a lovely apricot beer. There were a few fruit beers, a wide array of ale on tap and in bottles, ciders, spirits etc.Food was standard pub grub- burgers, so on. As it was a chain pub I assumed the food would be pretty good as you can usually count on a pub for a good, filling meal. I chose fish and chips. The chips were fine but I found the fish undercooked- it was hot but had an odd texture. It came out really quickly so I suppose they just bash everything out.It's not too surprising that the quality isn't great as it's in a very touristy area. I would definitely check this place out for the drinks and maybe get yourself a bowl of chips.

cAyHTBqcuDqPI2C9R0DxHQ.text: I thought this place would be a little more touristy since it's right next to the National Gallery. I think my wife and I might have been the only foreigners in there (other than the Aussie bartender.) They have a good selection of beers. I hear they get a pretty good crowd after work hours.

Y-_h7-vqbcZSpehjHpckYw.text: Lovely setting, and such a peaceful respite from the crowds just below. I expected it to be a lovely, atmospheric pub. But, I did NOT expect for the food to be as good as it was. Mind, the vegetables had been nuked to be re-heated (as was my entree, likely). But, it was still tasty and affordable, and a far cry above what you could get from nearby eatery, Pret.TIPS for Americans: if you are eating food, head upstairs and grab a table. Your table should have a number on it. Place your order at the bar, pay, and give them the number - they'll bring the food to you.

_g4hzjl9Ax44wcSyNFwbDw.text: Very well decorated samuel smith pub. Excellent beer for very little cost. This means it has plenty of seating and two floors. The upstairs is for drink and food, while the downstairs is for drinking only. No wifi or cell signal at all.

Ar_83CX8F4c7ooZVv_BtxQ.text: This is my favourite local haunt. As a Sam Smith pub my top picks will always be the fruity beers and a packet of their pork scratchings! The upstairs has a cosy feel, especially if you can nab a sofa seat or one of the window perches for two. Downstairs has more of a rough and ready vibe and works better for meets of big groups of people in my opinion! Only frustrating part is there's never any signal or wifi and in true classic Sam Smith style they don't offer any wifi.

9ufkfDgFXaKQCiIpPynIvw.text: What a great place to escape from the traffic and crowds of Trafalgar Square.  I prefer heading upstairs to the Opera room where there are cozy conversation areas in which to enjoy a great selection of beers and stouts, and I try to be there for lunch if possible.  I love the fish and chips, but the bangers and mash are great as well.  Friendly staff, prompt delivery from the kitchen, and the relaxed ambiance make this one of my favorite places in London.

MTPBzJ_Nzdftjj-qpEKSmQ.text: This is a Sam Smith brewery pub.. So the quality of drinks and food is top notch!They have vegan ales and lagers,Double Four and Sovereign are highly recommended. If downstairs is full, you can usually find a seat upstairs (even if your not eating). Good for one drink if you are passing by.. As it can be loud and busy due to it's location on the 'tourist trail'.

EpIwDwwAUT5FrQcrp2KPVA.text: Real old pub.Very loud the evening we went which was a Thursday.  There are two levels so seeing and hearing that there was a lads night out going on downstairs we went up stairs.  There is a bar up there also which is good and lots of sofas to kick back on and have your chat.  Did get a little loud but better than downstairs.Bar did not have a great wine selection but probably not the sort of place if you are looking to flick through a wine list.Close to the stations so good location for the drink on the way home from your night out in Covent Garden or Leicester Square.Noticed good old 'find us on Yelp' sticker on the door so 'go Chandos!'

photos.caption: Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom

iFjDXc1s5lsZIqt_TbWATA.text: This pub is great! Loved the drinks and atmosphere. Staff was friendly and pleasant to chat with. It's a great place to grab a drink if you're walking around the neighborhood or after work. Only reason I'm not giving 5 stars is because I didn't try any of their food so I feel like my review is not complete.

rsxbV_lJpHdJA2TELalKnA.text: One of the great London metropolitan pubs, just across from the National Portrait Gallery. Every visit of mine to London will inevitably result in at least half a dozen stints at this fine pub - and a dozen or more pints from their great range of Samuel Smith beers (and you can only get beers here from this brewery!). In recent years (after 2012) prices for beer in London have gone up rather sharply, so expect to pay UKP 4.90 for a pint of their signature lager, Pure Brewed Organic Lager - which is still cheaper than what an inferior lager will go for at other pubs in the area. Cheaper alternatives (like the Double-Brewed Lager or the Alpine and Taddy lagers) are available, but they are just not quite as good. A good, inexpensive option is the oak cask-aged Old Brewery Bitter, which is rather aromatic and costs below UKP 4. Various fruit beers are also available (Cherry, Strawberry, Raspberry & Apricot), but only from the bottle - they're good but don't come cheap at 5.70 for 355ml. Also, Samuel Smith makes one of the very few authentic German wheat beers, the Organic Wheat, in all of England - many have tried, but few have succeeded. It's also UKP 4.90/pint and on tap (as of August 2018). Other beers from their range - all of them from the bottle - that I can safely recommend are the Imperial Russian Stout, the Nut Brown Ale, the Oatmeal Stout, and the Taddy Porter. Nothing has changed décor-wise over the 14 years I've been frequenting The Chandos during my annual summer holidays (and several other trips to London): Particularly attractive, and correspondingly in demand, are the cute alcoves you can sit in, with their decorated stained glass windows and the large tables and comparatively comfortable benches. During peak hours you might as well forget about securing a place for you there. But the whole pub is rather comely, with its dark wooden furniture and the classy, old fashioned bar.They did however renovate the toilets (to be found in the basement) in recent years, and boy, was it necessary. I remember trying to find my way through the gents' loo with the flashlight of my smart phone when the lights were out - and the picture wasn't great. In August of 2018, I can happily report that the facilities I found were both neat and clean.On the upper level you will find the restaurant area (though you can also have meals on the ground floor), and that's the one quibble I have with their self-perception: The pub grub here is certainly competitive in price, but, personally, I wouldn't use the term "excellent" for it. I've had lunch there on a few occasions, and what I got was only standard pub food. Maybe they have improved in the past 5 years.The bar staff (mostly young men in their twenties) are very friendly indeed, and they're certainly doing their best trying to keep up with the queue of punters that will flood the place after office hours. So the best time to visit for a relaxed pint, sitting in an alcove, will be sometime soon after 12 a.m. - maybe after a visit to the National Gallery or National Portrait Gallery.

ONB__ImqH6JtkegCOk2uzA.text: Smooth atmosphere, nice staff.A little too much light, especially on the first floor. You can have a beer, cider and basic drinks. No selection of gin. No selection of wine. Disappointing.There is food to order (at the bar) upstairs. Fish and chips, etc.

photos.caption: Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom. Upstairs
Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom. Menu

rPjFC1GSbKpfZkc29-IyOg.text: The Chandos seems to cater to the tourist crowd, and they do it very well. Friendly staff, solidly good food, and the Samuel Smith on tap. I do want to recommend a veggie burger, which much to my surprise turned out to make my Top 10 list for veggie burgers worldwide. Served on a soft bun, it's a quinoa patty, fried perhaps with panko coating to give it some crunch, and with a discrete number of edamame beans thrown in. Excellent! The upstairs Opera Room, complete with with a variety of diva-themed posters and photos, is a pleasant enough space. If you've been walking all over the National Gallery across the street, this is a good place to stop in for a pint and quick lunch or a snack. As another Yelper put it, there's really nothing to complain about here.

7mvhAKb0_MRFKh6YSZL_-w.text: We were walking around looking for a place with great fish and chips and stumbled upon the chandos right as their kitchen was opening. The dining area is upstairs, we walked up and the staff was very polite and friendly. We ordered at the bar, fish and chips of course and the nachos to share. The dining area is very cozy and we grabbed a table in the back. The food was really good! The fish was perfectly crispy as were the chips, and the side of pees was delicious as well. By far the best fish and chips I have ever had! The nachos were good too and overall you get a large portion of food. I would definitely come back for the food again!

photos.caption: Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom. Nachos
Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom. Fish and chips

Vi3fzVih3FO57bpRxCAJJA.text: Came in here for a quick bite before we took a walking tour. I got a hand pie which was fairly good, there was a lot of gravy which helped. The carrots that came on the side were kind of hard, almost half cooked half not. My husband got the fish and chips, he said they were ok not the best he had in London but not the worst.

w6dw4hJhRMfSgs9km_FyyA.text: Best for me so far: Samuel Smith bitter on cask for £3.40, takes cards no problem, unbeatable location next to national gallery and the colosseum (where I was out for a show), clean inside, even a designer sink with soap and lotion pumps - nothing to complain of whatsoever.

vbFroz6_FyFsUfhWJq7agw.text: We checked around particularly for a good fish and chips place and all roads pointed back to here. The fish and chips hit the spot, and I'd highly recommend the dish to all lovers of fried fish. My girlfriend and I each ordered the fish and chips, and both were lightly fried, crispy, tender and fluffy on the inside, and served with fries and peas. We also ordered a side of chili nachos that were very satisfying and almost as good as the nachos that we have back in the states (partially joking).

photos.caption: Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom. Chili nachos
Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom. Fish and chips

RdQaQ6kYSIj3QJII8tqcew.text: Really fun pub; upstairs has genuinely good pub food, friendly efficient service even when very busy and great atmosphere.  Had first rate fish and chips with actual garden peas that weren't over cooked!  Pours Samuel Smith's excellent beers and ales on draft--outstanding stout, very good bitters, etc.--and definitely have the toffee dessert with custard.  Reasonable prices in a very touristy area and feels authentic where lots of places  around Trafalgar don't.

IjrZAG0ArzTVVkcMJwdsUQ.text: Fried, Crunchy, and Golden Perfection! If Fish and Chips is what you desire, then I highly recommend The Chandos. A place where the you can enjoy the classic pub atmosphere and while enjoying some classic english comfort food. The welcoming staff will make you feel right at home as you enjoy a bite into some of their delicious meals such as bangers and mash or even fish and chips. If you feel like exploring the beautiful wonders of the city, you are just in luck, as this pub is located right across from the National Portrait Gallery.

IXd5LM76SzyN6sEdA5_PdA.text: We stopped here after visiting the National Gallery. It was a short walk away. I ordered the fish and chips, and my husband ordered a chicken sandwich. The fish was long, flaky, and the batter was crisp. The chips were delightful. My husband's sandwich was just ok, and it didn't come with anything else, so we shared my chips and peas. It ended up being a perfect amount to share. The food was good, the environment was nice and cozy, and the toilets were clean and well-kept. My husband and I don't drink, so we can't speak to that part of this place. The food came out quickly, and the staff was friendly and kind. We would definitely come back to this place if we lived in London.

NCdCdkV-tGuKbTZXCCClZA.text: Not a neighborhood pub I spend my time inThe ground floor is cold with no warmth in the atmosphere or temperatureOrder up at the bar then stand around or try to find a seat at the few tables and high topsThe beer was good but I would expect thatThe guests were a mix of locals and a higher number of touristsI did not order the food along with the majority of the other patrons. Looks like this is a place for drinking and visiting before going out rather than a destination for eating throughout the night. With options so close, The Chandos pub does not feel like home to me. I'll move on.

mOs9I-mOY5Cr8dRuoScVew.text: My extended family of 6 (visiting from the USA) looked for and found this authentic English Pub.  We really enjoyed the food: Olives & Feta, Traditional Fish & Chips(X 3), Beef & Old Brewery Pie and a B.L.T.   Oh yes and a pint of dark beer to chase it down   The service was good and the toilettes were clean.

MJvfdpPErfP-vVrOkX18Mw.text: I'd have to agree with a prior reviewer who said "what more could you want from a pub?"  Good location, good food and good drinks. In fact, the food is better than most. Pricing is quite fair. Definitely worth a stop after the Portrait Gallery or other neighborhood sigjtseeif.

PNbdQn-feszLqfxYmg0CAQ.text: I scoured the internet for a place with reasonable food yet central for theatre in London - this was one of the pubs I came up with.  Took a shot on it and turned out liking it a lot.Great place for a beer in the afternoon.  Prices are very reasonable for central London, and the entire lower floor is simply for drinking (including outside).  Upstairs is where you can have food, seating is first come first serve and so you could be circling for awhile trying to find a table.  We lucked out and got one really quickly.  Food wasn't bad - I was hoping for a better portion.  We all got meat pies and they were a tad small with a small amount of potato as well.  I'd come back for food here and perhaps try something different.  All affordable options though.Typical pub - order at the counter and its brought out to you.  Pay at the counter as well.Central, affordable and nice.  A good find.

GvSMYsX8M4Pxw5uVQoEyXw.text: I ordered the fish and chips and the liver and onions. The were delicious and the price was definitely very reasonable for London standards. The fish was fresh and flakey, and the liver was really good with the sauce.

UZRcWL2SWXjWGS4WDcrHqQ.text: Self seating. Can get pretty busy. Place your order at the bar and food will be bought to your table. Food is pretty cheap i guess, but mediocre at best.

photos.caption: Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom

S3qUYUrDIL8cyPTFiKA_Vg.text: Maybe it's just me, but I'm not a fan of pub food. However, being tourists in London, we couldn't not have the pub experience. A quick Yelp search while waiting for our time slot for the London Eye led us to The Chandos. I feel like the great reviews are more for the selection of beers than their food. First off, if you wish to eat here, head upstairs and seat yourself. There's menus on the table, so when you're ready, go up to the bar and place your order - your order number will then be announced when ready; no service here really. My boyfriend and I split the steak and ale pie with a side of mashed potatoes and cabbage, along with the fish and chips with a side of mushy peas - the standard pub foods. We also had a beer that the bartenders recommended. Both dishes weren't bad, but they weren't good either.

photos.caption: Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Chandos - London, United Kingdom. Steak & ale pie, fish and chips in the back

aTYaR17B4SpaaIL8HmbrdA.text: Arrived about 8pm on Friday evening, for the fish and chips dinner others reviewed well. The place was packed. Good sign right? Nope. First floor chaos. Dirty glasses everywhere. Looked like 2 frazzled servers trying to keep up. No sign of food or menu anywhere. Then we saw the sign that food was served upstairs. Saved? Nope. Equally packed, less servers, no menus and no one eating. Not a single person having food. I guess if you're a 20 something hanging out and having a few beers this is the place to go. Just wasn't what we expected based on other reviews.

AZnNOvaattzaBBwAoKYDUQ.text: Loved the atmosphere. Very friendly and helpful staff. Steak and ale pie and burger were very good. Sticky toffee pudding was great. Lovely supper on our last night in England.

tDY06wXJr54FStylInpD2A.text: I've always thought "the chandos" is a bit of an odd name. Sounds a bit like a cheezy nightclub on Kefalonia. I don't really know where the name comes from, but what i do know is that they do cheap beer and it's only a stones throw from Trafalgar Square. Like every Sam Smith's pub, the beer gives you ridiculous hang overs. I guess that's the price you pay for cheap man in the box lager.

-ef4ZO0dWmQu1Twhuozdqg.text: Ein tolles Pub - in einer Ecke (NO) des Trafalgar Squares - das mit Gemütlichkeit und gutem Bier aufwartet.Das relativ preiswerte Hauptbier aus der Handpumpe ist Old Brewery Bitter der Brauerei Sam Smith. Natürlich gibt auch diverse andere Biere und den Apfelwein Cider.Das Pub ist nett und altmodisch eingerichtet, mit vielen hübschen Sitzecken. (Auch Sitzplätze im ersten Stock.)Die Bedienung ist freundlich und man kann dort auch ganz ordentlich essen.Das Richtige für wundfüßige Touristen.

gulF1ujZ7KJczClzhPZs9Q.text: Although the cheap pints (its a Sam Smith pub) are a bonus, the best thing about this pub is the building itself. Located right in the heart of tourist town (it's a stones throw from Trafagar Square), this pub is a great place to start off a night pre theatre or dinner. The upstairs with its booths and leather couches are cosy and the atmosphere is always good.

ud3GJ9Lt-3s5tf2U1_SkwQ.text: Just off Trafalgar Square, Chandos is one of the best central pubs I've come across. Part of the Sam Smiths chains, you get the standard mix of cheap lagers, ales and stouts, most very tasty and hovering just above the two pound mark. But you are not in cheap surroundings, there are some fantastic seating areas, comfy sofas, little snugs, the lot. The pub has two levels, the nicest being the cosier upstairs in my opinion, though this will give you a journey down two levels to get to the toilets, which is the only drawback to this place.

Mh0EWy72QmPXfAuRq2hZEQ.text: Really like this pub well of what i remember wasnt in here for long as was at work and popped in here for a sneeky drink after going to the pub For 11.00 it was fairly busy for a pub at that time.. i of course just had a fresh orange juice, collegue had coke and my manager has a beer (of course) and was at a good price!! Deco was really nice and fairly big too..

BK8qzCFDojmyqwi5W_p4xg.text: The Chandos pub is one of the great discoveries around Charing Cross. I think it was an old work colleague who first took me there. As part of the merry chain that is Sam Smith pubs, it is one of the cheapest pubs around. Located in the heart of theatre land it sits on the corner and has the old country pub feel to it the minute you walk in. There are selections of nice booths which are great to hang out in. It's a perfect meeting spot for a few cheeky cheap pints before you head on over to that fancy theatre or bourgeois nightclub.

2ziT4QY3PziKPJzJmjdTWQ.text: Though a chain pub and in one of the busiest, most touristy areas of central London, Chandos maintains a local homey feel, which provides a welcome respite from the surrounding area. By no means an oasis of calm, Chandos can become incredibly crowded on weekends and following rallies or other events on Traflagar Square. The lovely and simple wooden interior, high stools and comfortable corners make the visitor want to settle in for a while, drink a few pints and have a few laughs.

_y0DPT0VZTACzrDCHfXi7w.text: Cheap at ChandosChandos is another pub serving Sam Smiths beers. These are all nice beers and lagers, but the best part is that they are very cheap. Can you imagine paying less than £2 for a pint? You will here. The atmosphere is cosy and the staff are friendly. Head straight upstairs and plonk yourself into a seat for the evening.

P5WJsgUE-6BH8Wkpcpqm3w.text: Great little pub in the heart of the city which won't break your wallet. The drinks are all Sam Smith's own but go down easily enough. There's a drink for everyone (even if there is only a limited choice) including a good ale, stout, lager and assortment of spirits. Get there early though as it gets very busy in the evenings and you won't feed much in the way of seating after around 6pm.

1mS0jBPhrzUsYwMsvEItKw.text: Despite being city centre and a tourist magnet the Chandos is still a lovely bar to have a quiet drink with friends, be it one drink or an evening session you always feel welcome and the staff are friendly and efficient. The food here is good too and reasonably priced.

FaVS7QloeVJfpJgzBAZV0g.text: can be a bit touristy but other than that it's a great pub.

teeb0nOV7kicRYCJC0uqJg.text: cheap pub. but get there early as its always packed!

3lWHp46Ikl-uh7NsLF_AFw.text: The Chandos by Trafalgar Square is a Samuel Smiths pub; which means cheap drinks.The Chandos is arranged over two floors. The downstairs has a large bar, some seating booths along the walls and is rather open plan. The upstairs is more cosy with its own bar and a range of sofas and chairs. It is pleasant enough pub with a decent, though average, food menu. If you're in central and fancy a quick cheap drink it is a good option. Unfortunately, like a lot of Sam Smiths' pubs, it is a little lacking in character.

c0sVb3hCN0hj6gjxbKC2FA.text: The Chandos is everybody's favourite meeting place for an evening out in Central London. There are several reasons for this, the cheapness of the pints certainly being one! Owned by the Samuel Smith's chain, you are guaranteed a wide range of their own-branded beers, lagers and even spirits at credit-crunch-friendly prices. The pub's nicely done up, with a standy-uppy downstairs bar, and a more cosy upstairs area with some tables. Getting a seat is pretty much a once-in-a-lifetime occurrence, so enjoy it if it happens (I'm writing this because I got my first ever Chandos Seat last night - yay!) The pub, as other reviewers have mentioned, is usually crammed full, but this lends itself to a pleasantly buzzy atmosphere. It's nice to wander out, suitably fortified, and be on Trafalgar Square with St Martin-in-the-Fields right next to you, Nelson's Column and the National Gallery right ahead you get the picture.

kvGW_mZhZtp12txy4VrDWA.text: More specifically, The Opera Bar upstairs at the Chandos, with views across Charing Cross road to the National Gallery, is a fantastic bar to visit in the afternoons. There are so many padded chairs and sofas that if you're not sitting down you're doing something wrong. There are toilets for the upstairs bar hidden away at the far end, at a slightly higher level which reminded me of the ones in the Odeon in Manchester. This is a Samuel Smiths pub, so the beer and spirits are cheap and very good quality. Dare I say the best in London? Certainly the best value, about two pounds a pint (in London!!!) Since this bar catered to actors and singers, there are loads of photos of old stars on the wall, and a real club feel to the old place. Particularly when it's cold enough to have the coal fire burning. The staff were always attentive to me, but tended to ignore my Thai friend, so draw your own conclusions. I've also seen people playing board games in here, which I think they brought with them, so it's that kind of bar.

BjSadTQ-IG5TkT4NhCGKjA.text: Pretty comprehensive reviews about this pub which is a well-loved and popular place for many revellers right in the thick of things in town. A Sam Smiths - so home branded and fairly good value drinks are on offer. As many people have pointed out, the main lure is the Opera Room upstairs which serves food but sadly not at 9pm when we got there and it was heaving with drinkers. One of the best views from a ladie's loo in that part of London.

1uxU61Jj4UzrlPKp5kiSBw.text: Upstairs at the Candos is a great place to meet friends as there are large leather sofas and usually a fire to sit in front of too. The beer is very reasonably priced at around two pounds a pint. They do sell food too although I have never tried it, and I understand they stop selling it after something like seven in the evening. The downstairs bar tends to be more busy and has lots more poeple standing although there are seating booths down there too.

54IuGeMiWd4jv-R27eO4dQ.text: For being smack-dab in the most touristy part of London, this old pub has surprisingly cheap beer. Dark, stained-glass windows and lots of interior walls because of booths add character, but also make it very dim inside. With no outdoor seating (or pavement drinking, signs indicate this is not allowed) this isn't a good pub for a sunny day. On weekends it can get absolutely mobbed full of people. If it's a rainy day and you're waiting for someone in the neighbourhood it's a good place for a reasonably-priced pint.

zoRnTgyDiwvEYhhcMIQDgw.text: This is probably one of the best pubs in central London. Big but not heartless (like the chains). Cosy but spacious. Good beer that isn't the run-of-the-mill brands. This Sam Adams pub manages to combine a great location and venue with friendly bar staff and a lively atmosphere. A great place to meet up with friends of an evening, or even to spend drinking away the afternoon. For a London pub, this is about as cheap as it gets without selling your soul to Wetherspoons. What's more, the clientele are a discerning bunch, with nary an alcopop or upchucking teenager in sight. A perfect springboard for the clubs of the West End, or the place for a break from shopping and shows.

GnpYjCb5dc_EuLggwrZvPg.text: If I'm ever in the area and fancy a few drinks and a chat with someone, this is where I'll head to. The place is always fairly busy, but thankfully with enough floorspace both down and upstairs to not get too manic. Sam Smiths prices mean that your money will go far and you'll never remember the name of anything you've had to drink. It's a particularly good find considering the overpriced places that surround it.

55w-3G29R1y5tzzhIN1Upg.text: This pub gets 5 stars from me because its location is great just off charing cross road and the drinks are cheap. So you get value for money. I love the decor of the pub, its big and has a traditional feel to it. There are also private booths for groups to just sit down and mingle in private. which adds a nice feel to the pub. Great place i definately recommend it as top tree pubs in leicester square.

rvvSw_zq2FPK0ZFZxCzqkg.text: This is a little oasis in the centre of London. Just up from Trafalgar Square this is the perfect place to sink a few pints after you've feasted your eyes in the National Gallery or the National Portrait Gallery (which is practically opposite.) This is a Sam Smith's pub and the beer is well-kept and reasonably-priced. The pub itself is clean and comfortable and has numerous little cubbies and corners. Ideal for clandestine trysts with Camra members.

6JvCw6wF8X8Dv7bufJSZhg.text: Ah the good old Chandos - Always there to rely on when you need a super cheap drink and no-nonsense. Handily located between Charing cross and Leicester Square - Always a good meeting place for someone who doesn't know London that well. Also just to get them to experience a Man in a Box pint at some point. Not the best Sam Smith pub - I think the Ye Olde Cheshire cheese has more character but as they go, still very good.

w9cIJYEnmKHjNOnRnoKM1g.text: Located close to Trafalgar Square, this classic pub is a great place to grab a cheap lunch while seeing the sights.  On our recent (somewhat unplanned due to the volcano) trip to London, my husband and I managed to find the Chandos again.  We recalled the pub near the square with the cheap food and brews fondly from our last trip.For fish and chips, a ham and cheese toastie, a bowl of chips, and two beers, we shelled out just under 15 pounds.  The bartendress was really nice, despite the unbelievably rude French tourists who got snotty when she couldn't split a 35 pound bill 6 ways.  We'll definitely lunch at the Chandos on our next trip!

xMNTG0BBGnuuFk34nwOpfw.text: The best part about this place is the Opera Room upstairs - I've been coming here for years, and the standard of service is always good. It's a bit like sitting in a comfortable stately home study..big squashy leather sofas, muted colours, creaky floorboards, lots of opera-themed photos on the wall, (well it is next to the ENO!) - it's just a really comfortabe relaxed place to be during the day.It's a Sam Smiths pub, so that makes it a bit of shrine to some beer drinkers; it also does good pub grub at really sensible prices during the day.a great place to come and chill out with friends and have space to chat. In the evenings it has a much livelier vibe, but still friendly. Check it out!

TjBH07PebG35Q9p50KYg6w.text: The Chandos is the pub that I will always return to when venturing into the west end. Cheaper than many of its neighbours but without a bar full of Jeremy Kyle participants like you find in Wetherspoons, the Chandos is a vibrant and atmospheric pub. On two floors with many different nooks to hide away in as well as sofas to lounge on, the Chandos is a great place to while away some time with friends. Also, the positioning of the toilets make it one of the best places in London to sneak in and use the loos for free.

vP2k8llZaeDqGjrq1lE_8w.text: Great London pub at remarkable prices. don't go here if you looking for the national brands. All the beer sold here is brewed by Samuel Smiths of Tadcaster, Yorkshire. A pint of Old Brewery Bitter, a decent hand pulled beer, for less than £2 in central London. The atmosphere is always good, with a mix of office workers and tourists. Ideal for the National Gallery and The Collosuem. The upstairs bar offers food and more comfortable surroundings

Itj6gan2XOCT-l4IRAETHw.text: Excellent Sam Smiths pub just off Trafalgar Square. Upstairs rooms are a great meeting place and is popular for reunions. Gets very crowded especially in the evenings, but it isn't hard to see why.

dXZQUyiasbpLuiTqIQ0JGQ.text: The Chandos sells beer that is sourced from the company's own brewery.  Last time I had a pint in here it tasted like cereal.  There was just something desperately wrong with the flavour.  It was also £4, which I think is an absolute rip off, especially considered that it tasted like mutant Cornflakes.  The atmosphere in here is very touristy.  It feels like a swarm of foreigners come here looking for authenticity, but this doesn't feel like a traditional English pub to me.  This place feels like Disneyland with booze.

02vF9j1OPMsvQdG2WGfTLA.text: the chandos is a samual smiths bar in trafalger square.  i found this place for the first time 4 years ago.  i love it!  they make everything in the bar from the scotch and whiskey to all of the lagers and ales.  it's a great place to meet other tourists as well as real londoners.  i found the service to real slow since no one in london works for a tip.  however that was the only draw back.  i did like drinking outside.  everyone does it even though there was a sign saying i couldn't.  i would avoid this place on friday and sat nights.  it packs out with every 18 year old (18 is the legal age for drinking in the UK) from the country side and it can get a little aggressive in there.  the food is decent.  it's basic stuff like bangers and mash, fish and chips and spotted dick for dessert.  thanks again chandos. you did not disappoint.  i dropped one star because of the kids being aggressive.

jUlAY4SOuDSx1s2z9pSVWg.text: The best thing about this pub (apart from it's easy location near to Charing Cross Station) is the opera bar upstairs - if you can get here early (i.e. before 7pm) you can bag a really comfy seat! It used to be so smoky in here that non-smokers like me hated it but now it's fab. A great place to meet mates after work and not worry about having to stagger miles to get home - you're right by a huge tube or rail station and all the night buses!

5pXbNmRe3T9VwBqWNSfFqQ.text: My other half's a big Sam Smiths fan, so it's fair to say we spend a lot of time in the Chandos when we're in London. Great beer - and cider! at reasonable prices for the capital. Like the other reviewers say, try to sit upstairs if you can - squishy sofas and shabby chich rule but it's a lovely place to while away the afternoon with some beers and a natter.
